RCOG does not recommend using any medication labelled ‘abortion reversal’ as this is misleading. There's no evidence to support the use of progesterone to reverse the effects of mifepristone. It's concerning that some websites are advertising this service: https://t.co/5rb6kBDOrg

.@FCDOGovUK must reposition itself as a leading donor and return its funding commitment to SRHR to give women and girls around the world greater choice and opportunities #SRHR  #healthforall #UKaidcuts https://t.co/4waYZ7hJ6Z (3/3)

The UK has long been a leader in global health initiatives for sexual and reproductive health and maternal health. @FCDOGovUK has the opportunity to re-establish its reputation as by returning to 0.7% and committing 5% of ODA, currently around £500 million, to SRHR. (2/3)

The RCOG applauds the ambitions @FCDOGovUK has laid out in its new Health Systems Strengthening and Ending Preventable Deaths Approach papers . To deliver these ambitious agendas it is critical that the Government restores its 0.7% commitment. (1/3)

We welcome the decision by MLAs to defeat the Severe Fetal Impairment Bill in Northern Ireland yesterday, which sought to restrict the rights of women to make choices about their own healthcare and to force them to travel to access a vital service. #NowforNI https://t.co/VLoQ0NuAt8
The RCOG stands in support with the women of NI who wish to make their own decisions about their healthcare and urges all MLA's to oppose this regressive Bill. (3/3)

Any woman with a diagnosis of severe fetal impairment will be forced to continue the pregnancy to term, which puts their own lives at risk. Or they could be forced to travel to Great Britain to seek an abortion. (2/3)

Right now the NI Executive considers the Severe Fetal Impairment Abortion (Amendment) Bill which seeks to remove the rights of women in Northern Ireland to obtain an abortion in cases of severe fetal impairment. (1/3)

Although the increases in risk discussed are statistically significant, we want to reassure women there is still only a small risk to the individual.

Investment in renewable energy generation and energy efficiency businesses must be part of a healthy and sustainable recovery from the pandemic, including phasing out coal power by 2024, and ending investment in all fossil fuel projects abroad.
Further investment in air pollution monitoring and research is essential. Action and research must also focus on most vulnerable groups and the heavier toll on deprived communities.

A reduction in road transport of all kinds is needed to minimise the health impacts of air pollution – we need ambitious and equitable investment to support and promote active, green and shared travel, alongside curbing emissions through initiatives such as Clean Air Zones.
The UK Government must show strong international leadership and adopt legal limits on particulate matter which at least meet WHO guidelines, to be met by 2030 at the latest.

We have published a position statement on outdoor air pollution and pregnancy today to mark #CleanAirDay. Our recommendations are in short below, read more on our website: https://t.co/HBKPWovMLe https://t.co/BRgMKVe353

From today, face masks and coverings must be worn by all NHS hospital staff, visitors and outpatients in England, including pregnant women attending antenatal appointments or scans. At present hospital inpatients, including women giving birth, are not required to wear masks.

✅ Pregnant women, including those from a BAME background, who develop more severe symptoms of coronavirus, or feel their recovery is delayed, may be developing more severe illness and need enhanced care. In these cases, they should contact NHS 111 or their maternity unit.
✅Healthcare professionals should be aware of this increased risk, and have a lower threshold to review, admit and consider multidisciplinary escalation in pregnant women from a BAME background.

✅Pregnant women from a BAME background should be told at each contact with a health professional that they may be at higher risk of complications of coronavirus, and advised to seek help early if they are concerned about their health.

Read our policy statement on racial disparities in women’s healthcare 👇
https://t.co/VHp6FrBhH7 5/5

What we do know is that people from BAME communities are likely to be at increased risk of #COVID19 due to social and economic factors. Also, BAME people are likely to be at greater risk of poorer outcomes due to health conditions, such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease 4/5

It's still unknown why #COVID19 affects people from a BAME background, as these latest analyses did not consider the effect of occupation, pre-existing health conditions or obesity among other factors 3/5

These shocking statistics confirm what we already know: #COVID19 disproportionately affects people from a Black, Asian or other ethnic minority background. It's extremely concerning that #covid19 has reinforced existing health inequalities. In some cases, these have increased 2/5

Together with @midwivesRCM and the @FOMNews, we will continue to ensure pregnant women, including healthcare workers, get the advice and support they need at this challenging time, based on the best available evidence.

Employers should undertake a risk assessment and involve occupational health to determine whether women under 28 weeks pregnant can continue working in public-facing roles. Pregnant women who are more than 28 weeks can only continue working where the risk assessment supports this

We have revised the advice to clarify that responsibility for risk assessment in the workplace lies with the employer. These updates are in response to feedback we have received from individuals and charities supporting pregnant women whom we would like to thank.

👍🏼Importantly, these contraceptive options will give women and their partners the choice of controlling their fertility and planning when they next become pregnant 🤱🏼 Read more on the link below  https://t.co/uqRSqBU8us
✅In some maternity units, women will also have the option of having the copper intrauterine device or the hormone-releasing intrauterine system fitted during a caesarean birth.
✅ A six month-supply of the progestogen-only pill (POP) can be offered to women after childbirth, unless they have a medical reason not to.
✅ Most contraceptive methods (except the combined pill, patch and vaginal ring) can be started safely immediately after giving birth, including women who are fully breastfeeding.

📢Therefore, we recommend women should be able to access effective contraception as soon as possible after childbirth in maternity settings. This will help to limit the number of visits to health services and reduce  risk of #COVID19 transmission among women and healthcare staff.

➡️Sexual activity and fertility may return quickly after childbirth, and pregnancies soon after giving birth may increase the risk of complications.

➡️Yet we know access to contraception in GP practices and clinics has been reduced due the #COVID19 pandemic.

We have published new recommendations to enable women to access contraception in maternity units after giving birth during #coronavirus

Read the news: https://t.co/eTsXq2fbFE

The evidence base for this new virus is growing rapidly. As and when new information emerges, we will issue new guidance. 

We hope this thread has brought clarity around the guidance and will help pregnant health workers and their employers.
We are acutely aware of the current realities of frontline NHS care, including PPE provision and are urgently feeding back all concerns to PHE, NHS leadership and Government.

We have developed this guidance with the UK Chief Medical Officers to enable women and their employers to more effectively plan their working patterns and continue to make a valuable contribution to the workplace until the start of their maternity leave.
We understand the uncertainty about the risks posed by coronavirus to pregnant women and their babies is causing substantial difficulties and confusion for women, their families and their employers.
We also know that for pregnant women who become seriously unwell with coronavirus in the 3rd trimester, their baby may need to be born early to enable the mother to recover.
We know pregnant women who contract other respiratory viruses in the later stages of pregnancy after 28 weeks are more likely to become seriously unwell.
The Government has taken the precautionary view that it is particularly important that pregnant women after 28 weeks are not exposed to coronavirus.
There is no evidence that #coronavirus is more dangerous to pregnant women than other healthy adults, or any evidence to suggest coronavirus causes miscarriage or babies to develop abnormally.

The report makes recommendations to improve care and these are grouped into the following themes:

✅Better team working and behaviour
✅Addressing workload and workforce challenges
✅Improving communication 

Read more below 👇https://t.co/zoUMEj9SJS

The number of local maternity reviews into these cases that contained sufficient information for analysis has grown year on year, 95% in 2017 from 75% in 2015.

✅ This helps to improve our understanding of how to prevent any avoidable cases of deaths and injuries in the future.

Parents being invited to contribute to the local review of their baby's case rose to 493 (50%) of cases in 2017, compared with 34% in 2015. 

While this is an improvement, it is important for every parent to be made aware of any investigation and be invited to participate. https://t.co/LzJ8oSx73s
The number of babies reviewed where different care might have led to a different outcome was slightly lower at 72% of babies in 2017, compared to 76% in 2015. https://t.co/SsvpLMupp0

In total, 1,130 babies met the eligibility criteria for 
@EachBabyCounts, out of 677,192 babies born at term in 2017. Sadly, there were:

▶️130 stillbirths
▶️150 babies born alive following labour but who died within the first 7 days 
▶️850 babies who had severe brain injury https://t.co/nXy0hmQTDj

We are calling for the new framework on abortion care to be part of a holistic, integrated sexual and reproductive healthcare service in Northern Ireland. #womenshealth #northisnow https://t.co/c8MtPlbQM2 https://t.co/sQyDyozwKC

We are urging the Government to introduce a legal framework which will allow best-practice care without introducing unnecessary barriers and restrictions. 
#womenshealth #northisnow  
https://t.co/c8MtPlbQM2 https://t.co/idFYTubSwn

For too long women in desperate circumstances have been unable to access abortion care in Northern Ireland. 

The new framework is the perfect opportunity to deliver what is an essential part of sexual and reproductive healthcare. 

https://t.co/c8MtPlbQM2 https://t.co/pK28i3X9kV

@MidwivesRCM @FSRH_UK We are therefore strongly encouraging the Government to establish a legal framework which removes the barriers to abortion care and ensures the needs of girls and women are met in Northern Ireland.

@MidwivesRCM @FSRH_UK There is no clinical basis for introducing a restriction at 12 or 14 weeks, and introducing such restrictions would present difficulties, including women having to travel to the rest of the UK to complete their abortions – which would represent a failed regulatory framework.

@MidwivesRCM @FSRH_UK Our professional groups agree that restricting access to abortion care at arbitrary gestations before 24 weeks will only create barriers for women, and harm the most vulnerable or disadvantaged who are more likely to present at later gestations.
https://t.co/c8MtPlbQM2

We are calling for the future legal framework to focus on safe and compassionate abortion care in Northern Ireland. 

Read our full statement with @MidwivesRCM and @FSRH_UK: https://t.co/c8MtPlbQM2
https://t.co/jA8zSmLyV0 #womenshealth #northisnow
